2024_10_1890_1901_EN.summary:
Case Summary: The case involves Bijay Agarwal who appealed against orders passed by the Principal City Civil & Sessions Judge at Bangalore in Criminal Appeals Nos. 1537/2023 and 1536/2023. The orders imposed a condition requiring the appellant to deposit 20% of the fine amount payable under CC Nos. 13937/2023 and 13938/2013.

Key Issues:
- Whether the Appellate Court should have considered exceptional circumstances before exempting the appellant from depositing the fine amount under Section 148(1) of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881.
- Whether the High Court failed to consider crucial aspects while considering the suspension of sentence for the conviction under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act in the pending appeal.

Legal Analysis: The Supreme Court held that the Appellate Court should have considered whether the case falls within exceptional circumstances before exempting the appellant from depositing the fine amount payable under Section 148(1) of the Negotiable Instruments Act. The court found that the High Court failed to consider crucial aspects while considering the suspension of sentence for the conviction under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act in the pending appeal. The court directed the First Appellate Court to dispose of the appeals expeditiously.

Relevant Sections:
- Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881: Section 138 (dishonour of cheque), Section 148 (deposit of fine amount pending appeal)

Judgment: The Supreme Court quashed and set aside the orders dated 10.11.2023 passed by the Principal City Civil & Sessions Judge at Bangalore in Criminal Appeal Nos. 1537/2023 and 1536/2023, to the extent they imposed the condition to deposit 20% of the fine amount payable under orders in CC Nos. 13937/2023 and 13938/2013. The appeals were allowed accordingly.

2023_10_842_847_EN.summary:
Case Summary: The case involves a challenge to the jurisdiction of the National Investigation Agency (NIA) in investigating six FIRs registered between March 30 and April 3, 2023, which were initially handled by state police authorities in West Bengal.

Key Issues:
- Whether the Central Government has the power to handover investigation to the NIA under Section 6(5) of the National Investigation Agency Act, 2008, once it has been completed by the District Police (Issue 1).
- Whether the Order of Sanction dated July 22, 2020, issued under Section 45(2) of the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act (UAPA) suffers from any illegality (Issue 2).
- Whether the order taking cognizance against the petitioner under Sections 120B IPC, 17 UAPA, and 17 Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1908 is valid (Issue 3).

Legal Analysis: The Supreme Court determined that the NIA has exercised its jurisdiction specifically with reference to its powers under Section 6(5) of the National Investigation Agency Act, 2008. The court clarified that it is not called upon to decide on the sufficiency of the allegations or their veracity but rather whether the exercise of jurisdiction by the Central Government under Section 6(5) is valid. The court affirmed the judgment of the High Court, confirming that the NIA's exercise of jurisdiction was proper.

Relevant Sections:
- National Investigation Agency Act, 2008: Section 6(5)
- Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act: Section 45(2), Section 17
- Indian Penal Code: Section 120B (criminal conspiracy)
- Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1908: Section 17

Judgment: The Special Leave Petitions were disposed of. The observations made by the High Court in the impugned order were confined to the question of whether the exercise of jurisdiction by the NIA under the National Investigation Agency Act, 2008 is valid. For these reasons, the court affirmed the judgment of the High Court.

Key Entities:
- Parties: The State of West Bengal & Ors. (Petitioners), Suvendu Adhikari & Ors. (Respondents)
- Judges: Dr. Dhananjaya Y. Chandrachud (Chief Justice of India)
- Case Number: SLP(Crl) No. 842-847 of 2023
- Dates: March 30, 2023 (notification), May 8, 2023 (registration of FIRs), April 27, 2023 (High Court directions), May 11, 2023 (cognizance taken), July 22, 2020 (sanction order)
- Court: Supreme Court of India
